description: From Middle English houten, huten, hoten, of North Germanic origin, from or related to Old Swedish huta (“to cast out in contempt”), related to Middle High German hiuzen, hūzen (“to call to pursuit”), Swedish hut! (“begone!”, interjection), Dutch hui (“ho, hallo”), Danish huj (“ho, hallo”).

examples: I heard the hoot of an owl.

entries.meaning: (slang) A fun event or person. (See hootenanny)
examples: The party at the weekend was such a hoot! Thanks for the invite.

entries.meaning: A small particle; a whit or jot.
examples: We don't care a hoot about what you think.

verbs.description: hoot (third-person singular simple present hoots, present participle hooting, simple past and past participle hooted)

entries.meaning: To cry out or shout in contempt.
To make the cry of an owl, a hoo.
examples: The clamorous owl that nightly hoots and wonders / At our quaint spirits.

entries.meaning: To assail with contemptuous cries or shouts; to follow with derisive shouts.
examples: Mary felt extremely offended when the workers hooted at her.

entries.meaning: To sound the horn of a vehicle
examples: When you arrive to pick me up, hoot, and I'll come outside.
